explanation:
For deciding whether code in MHD_poll_all is dead (i.e. its removal would not change observable program behaviour) you must know all symbols that affect control flow, side-effects, conditional compilation and observable outputs. Brief reasons by symbol/category: 

Daemon struct fields (daemon->*): these fields are read or written throughout MHD_poll_all and determine which branches execute (e.g. whether listen fd is polled, whether new connections are processed, whether shutdown causes early return, whether suspension handling changes timeout). Without their definitions/semantics you cannot tell if a block is reachable or if its removal would change behaviour. 

Compile-time flags (MHD_USE_SELECT_INTERNALLY, MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME, HTTPS_SUPPORT, UPGRADE_SUPPORT): these control which code is compiled or which runtime conditions are meaningful (e.g. HTTPS/upgrade-related code presence). Dead-code analysis must know whether those macros are defined. 

Socket / poll constants (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET, POLLIN, POLLOUT, MHD_POLL_EVENTS_ERR_DISC, MHD_POLL_REVENTS_ERR_DISC): these constants govern poll setup and revent checks; their meanings determine whether branches (event handling, error checks) are operational or no-ops. 

Thread/ID checks (MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_ID_, MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_): used in asserts that may be compiled in/out; their presence/behaviour affects whether assertions are considered reachable runtime behaviour. 

resume_suspended_connections: return value changes millisec and therefore timeout/poll behaviour; removing the code that sets millisec could change timing/behaviour, so understanding this function is essential. 

Memory/allocation and poll buffer (MHD_calloc_, free, struct pollfd): allocation failure leads to early return; determining whether allocation+free sequences are dead requires knowing allocation semantics and whether p is used meaningfully. 

Timeout computation and poll (get_timeout_millisec_int, MHD_sys_poll_, MHD_socket_get_error_, MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_EINTR_, MHD_socket_strerr_): these determine whether the sys_poll call can block/return, whether error handling paths execute, and whether EINTR handling causes early returns. They are critical to judge if error-handling branches or retry logic are dead. 

Inter-thread communication (MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_, MHD_itc_r_fd_, MHD_itc_clear_): the ITC FD handling is an explicit branch; knowing whether ITC is present and what clearing does is needed to decide whether that block contributes behaviour. 

Connection-related helpers (new_connections_list_process_, MHD_accept_connection, call_handlers and the connection/upgrade helpers urh_to_pollfd, urh_from_pollfd, process_urh, MHD_connection_finish_forward_, MHD_resume_connection): these functions perform the real work on connections; determining whether their invocation sites are dead requires knowing their side-effects on connections, lists, and daemon state (they can add/remove connections or change daemon->have_new etc.). 

Return/result constants and type (MHD_YES, MHD_NO, enum MHD_Result): to decide whether returning early from various branches is semantically relevant you must know the meaning of these results. 

Logging and diagnostics (MHD_DLOG, MHD_strerror_, errno): logging calls are observable side-effects; depending on the project's definition of behaviour (especially for MISRA dead-code which considers observable behaviour), logging removal may or may not be considered dead. Include these so the analyst can judge if removing logging constitutes change in behaviour. 

In short: all listed symbols either affect branching/looping, perform side-effects that change program state or outputs, or control conditional compilation. Without them you cannot determine whether any particular statement/block in MHD_poll_all is removable without changing the program, so they are required for a sound dead-code analysis.
